Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Story: I was sitting in the lifeguard office, glancing over my notes from my mentor. There was a term in the training manual I didn’t quite understand, and I knew I was supposed to reach out to my mentor whenever I hit a snag, no matter how small. That was the expectation—open communication, no hesitation. But as I pulled out my phone to draft a quick message, I noticed the lane rope in the pool had snapped. Swim lessons were starting soon, and as a lifeguard, it was my responsibility to make sure all equipment was in perfect condition. If I didn’t fix it right away, the lessons could be delayed, or worse, someone could get hurt. My mentor expected me to be proactive and transparent, but my supervisor expected the pool to be ready and safe. I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between sending that message and grabbing the repair kit. Both roles demanded my attention, and I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing down, forcing me to choose which responsibility mattered more in this moment.
